Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading statements in tax returns
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax penalty and interest relief dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed ignorance and reliance on third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of ignorance and reliance on third party not deemed credible or sufficient
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) allows waiver only if extraordinary circumstances beyond taxpayer’s control exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for relief from penalties and interest due to alleged misunderstanding
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Minister of National Revenue / CRA Officer
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of compliance history, due diligence, and nature of error
Crimes.Legal_Framework: ITA and CRA policy guidelines (e.g., IC 92-2)
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Denial of relief request under ITA subsection 220(3.1)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained denial based on absence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and declarative evidence regarding remittance practices
Crimes.Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative decision subject to judicial review
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Ignorance of law and third-party error do not constitute extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Request for relief followed by judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Federal Court / Tax Court of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to remit CPP contributions, citing ignorance and third-party advice
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for relief denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failure to fulfill statutory remittance obligations
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Existence of extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Compliance history, due diligence, credibility of explanation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's justification not considered credible or exceptional
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Records of non-payment, lack of prior compliance
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for administrative relief from penalties
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Nature and cause of failure to remit
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Public revenue loss due to non-remittance
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: ITA payroll deduction and remittance requirements
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – error due to omission, not false statement
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignorance and third-party errors insufficient for relief
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Extraordinary circumstances test under ITA s. 220(3.1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to withhold Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax penalty and interest relief dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant cited ignorance and third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Explanation lacked credibility as a basis for relief
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Waiver allowed only under extraordinary circumstances beyond taxpayer’s control
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for penalty/interest relief due to claimed ignorance
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of compliance history and due diligence
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Denial of relief under ITA s. 220(3.1)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA emphasized statutory responsibility lies with employer
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Ordinary negligence or ignorance does not qualify as extraordinary circumstance

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to remit Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax penalty and interest relief dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to show extraordinary circumstances; relied on ignorance and third-party error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to prove eligibility for relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Reliance on third party not excusable under law
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extraordinary circumstances required for waiver under s. 220(3.1)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for cancellation of penalties/interest based on misunderstanding
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Payment history, compliance record, explanation provided
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Denial of relief under ITA s. 220(3.1)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained that statutory duty cannot be delegated
Crimes.Resolution_Mechanism: Internal CRA review followed by judicial review
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Ignorance of law and delegation to third party are not valid grounds
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Federal Court / Tax Court of Canada
